questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Wernicke's Broca's Global Conduction Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Posterior (fluent) transcortical Isolation Anomic Pure Word Deafness Pure Alexia
Comprehension Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved Impaired only for spoken language Impaired only for reading
Repetition of Spoken language Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved Preserved Echolalia Preserved Impaired Preserved
Naming Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved Preserved 
Fluency Preserved Decreased Decreased Preserved Impaired Preserved No purposeful speech Preserved except for word finding pauses Preserved Preserved

questions.text: 24-year-old presents with intensely itchy lesion for three days. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is a ring lesion with a central clearing suggestive of tinea corporis.

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. 

Other options:

Option B: Granuloma annulare is a circular lesion with central clearing found most commonly in children and in adult females <30 years. They usually manifest as groups of 1- to 2-mm papules that range in color from skin-colored to violaceous, often in an annular arrangement over distal extremities.

Option C: Ichthyosis Vulgaris presents with dry scaly lesions in infants. Fine scales usually develop on the back and over skin near the knee/elbow joints. Ichthyosis is usually most common and severe over the lower legs.

Option D: Pyoderma gangrenosum, chronic, recurrent, very painful neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders usually found on the lower limbs. It is usually associated with Inflammatory Bowel disease.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching and green frothy discharge in a young female with strawberry vagina points towards trichomoniasis. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for trichomoniasis.

It is is the most common parasitic infection in humans in the industrialized world.

It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, an anaerobic, flagellated protozoa, exists only as a trophozoite (no cyst stage).

Diagnosis is made by detection of motile flagella during microscopic examination of wet mounts. Direct immunofluorescent antibody staining is more sensitive (70-90%) than wet mount.

Culture is done on Feinberg-Whittington media.

Treatment: DOC- Metronidazole 2 gm single oral dose. All sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males. Tinidazole can also be used for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

questions.text: Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for external beam radiotherapy in the treatment of cancer patients?
questions.solution:
• Cobalt-60 isotope is used for EBRT (external beam radiotherapy).
  • Cobalt and LINAC (Linear Accelerator) machines are used for giving external beam radiotherapy.
  • In Cobalt machine, Co 60 isotope is used. They emit radiation of energy 1.25 Mev. Gamma rays produced by cobalt machine is used for radiotherapy.
  • LINAC (Linear Accelerator) machine’s cancer therapy is based on X-ray generation and not based on the isotope. The continuous spectrum of different energy radiations is produced that is orthovoltage, supervoltage and megavoltage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of VIPoma?
questions.solution:
VIPoma is associated with metabolic acidosis and not alkalosis.

In VIPoma, excessive vasoactive intestinal peptide leads to diarrhoea, which in causes bicarbonate and fluid losses. This results in metabolic acidosis.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma)/Verner–Morrison syndrome/WDHA syndrome:

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has been treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for 4 months. The disease still progresses. What is your recommendation for further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine is indicated in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis when the disease is not responding to methotrexate alone.

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, a 1- to 2-week burst of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Anti-TNF alpha agents/Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules.

They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset breathlessness. He has undergone hip replacement one month back. As a physician, you are suspecting a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for your diagnosis?

choices.text: Ventilation perfusion scanning (V/Q scan) of lungs

questions.solution:
CT chest with intravenous contrast is the investigation of choice for pulmonary embolism (PE).

Other options:

  • Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q ) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.
  • MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation perfusion scan can be done. 
  • Echocardiography is not a reliable diagnostic imaging tool for acute PE because most patients with PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

 

 

The arrows in the following images demonstrate a pulmonary embolus. Also the gross specimen image helps correlation.

questions.text: What structure involved in parotid gland surgery is shown by the arrow?
questions.solution:
• The structure shown is the main trunk of the facial nerve.
  • The facial nerve can be identified during parotid surgery by using certain landmarks. These landmakrs are as follows:
    • The inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. This is termed a Conley's pointer and indicates the position of the facial nerve, which lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
    • The upper border of the posterior belly of the digastric
  • It can also be identified by tracing the nerve back from its terminal branches and by using a nerve stimulator.
  • Frey syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from damage to the autonomous innervation of the salivary gland with inappropriate regeneration of parasympathetic nerve fibers that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin.
    • It is diagnosed by the starch-iodine test.

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
The murmur of HOCM increases on standing.

Standing decreases the preload and it leads to an increase in the obstruction and intensity of the murmur.

The murmur of HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. S1 is normal, S2 can be either single or paradoxical splitting of S2 is seen. S4 is heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect
Inspiration (↑venous return to right atrium) ↑ intensity of right sided sounds
Hand grip (↑afterload ) ↑ intensity of MR, AR and VSD murmurs
↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
MVP: delayed onset of click / murmur
Valsalva-Phase II, standing up (↓ preload) ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur
Rapid squatting (↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)		 ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
↑ intensity of AS, MR and VSD murmurs
MVP: later onset of click / murmur

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with complaints of severe pain in her left great toe. The pain started since she woke up in the morning and severe to an extent that she is not able to stamp her foot on the ground. A local examination of her foot is given in the image below. Which of the following investigations is least useful in arriving at a diagnosis?

choices.text: Needle aspiration of the synovial fluid

questions.solution:
The symptoms and the clinical examination findings are suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Serum uric acid level is least useful in arriving at a diagnosis of gout.

During an acute attack of gout, the inflammatory cytokines promote the excretion of uric acid and hence, its level can be normal or decreased at such instances. This limits the use of serum uric acid level for the diagnosis of gout.

Even if the diagnosis of gout is clinically strong, it should ideally be confirmed by needle aspiration of the involved joint. The synovial fluid aspirated from the inflamed joints has the following features

  • Needle shaped monosodium urate (MSU) crystals which appear brightly birefringent with negative elongation under polarised microscopy.
  • The leukocyte counts are elevated from 2000 to 60,000/μL and give a cloudy appearance of the aspirated fluid

Ultrasound may aid in the earlier diagnosis by showing a double contour sign overlying the articular cartilage.

questions.text: The Father of interventional radiology is:
questions.solution:
Charles Theodore Dotter was a pioneering US vascular radiologist who is credited with developing interventional radiology. He performed the very first peripheral angioplasty in 1964.

Roentgen discovered X-rays.

Sir Godfrey Hounsfield developed the first CT machine in 1970. Hounsfield is a unit used to describe the density of tissues on a CT scan.

Robert Egan is the Father of modern mammography.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient came to the emergency with pain in the epigastrium radiating to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, guarding was present in the upper epigastrium. The erect chest X-ray was normal. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis. The normal erect chest X-Ray indicates probably there was no pneumoperitoneum effectively ruling out perforation. 

So, in this setting, the main differential to consider would be pancreatitis for which the next appropriate investigation would be serum lipase.

Related Pearl: Causes of acute pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

questions.text: The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is_____
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is epidural blood patch. The remaining options are conservative management approaches for PDPH.

Procedure:

  • Ideally, performed 24 hours after dural puncture and development of classic PDPH symptoms.

  • 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture.

  • It acts by stopping CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation.

 

Approximately 90% of patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury.What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The image is of battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process.

Middle Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Anterior Cranial Fossa Fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called_______.
questions.solution:
This suture technique is called mattress suture. The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.

Other options :

B) The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end.

C)Continuous suture technique is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edges of the wound, this is performed continuously till the end is reached.

D) Interrupted suture technique is performed inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and crossing both the edge of the wound and the knot is tied.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with reddening and itching over the left breast as shown in the figure. Mammogram showed the presence of microcalcifications in the left breast. Histopathology shows the presence of large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are diagnostic of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a superficial manifestation of underlying malignancy.

Clinically it presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. In the majority of patients, there is also an underlying breast lump. This lump is usually DCIS. Less commonly it can also be invasive ductal carcinoma.

A nipple biopsy specimen will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei is pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Paget's disease can be often confused with superficial spreading melanoma. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity and rash on her face as seen below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The rash visualized in the image is a malar rash (classically seen in SLE), it is characterized by a well demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

In decreasing order, the cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

  • Photosensitivity (63%)
  • Raynaud's Phenomenon (60%)
  • Malar Rash (51%)
  • Chronic Urticaria >36 hrs (44%)
  • Non-scarring Alopecia (40%)
  • Mouth Ulceration (31%)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known case of type 1 DM presents with confusion. The blood glucose level is 353 mg/dl and pH-7.0. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Metabolic abnormality in the above condition is metabolic acidosis. It is due to diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) which is a complication of type 1 DM.

In DKA, insulin to glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to the acidosis

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 30 years old male presents with continuous discomfort in the right hypochondrium and on examination shows presence of enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins. The image below shows CT radiograph. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The above image shows CT scan of the liver with hydatid cyst seen as a hypodense lesion with internal septation.

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

Causative agent:

There are two main strains which include:

  1. Echinococcus granulosus: more common
    • pastoral: dog is a main host; most common form
    • sylvatic: wolf is a main host
  2. Echinococcus alveolaris/multilocularis: less common but more invasive; fox is a main host

Investigation:

  • CT examination reveals fluid density cyst, with frequent peripheral focal areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • Septation and daughter cysts may be visualised. The water-lily sign indicates a cyst with floating, undulating membrane, caused by a detached endocyst.
  • May also show hyperdense internal septa representing a spoke wheel pattern within a cyst.

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is:
questions.solution:
The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD (stage IV) is FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%.  

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:  

GOLD Stage Severity Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic who hasn’t taken alcohol for 3 days presented to the emergency department with features of disorientation, poor attention span, agitation, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and fever. The condition is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of disorientation with features of autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever) in a patient who stopped alcohol 3 days back is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal.

Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Other options:

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is characterized by ataxia (affecting primarily the gait), vestibular dysfunction, confusion, and ocular motility abnormalities.
  • Korsakoffs psychosis is characterized by impaired mental syndrome (especially recent memory) and anterograde amnesia in an alert and responsive patient. The patient may or may not have the symptom of confabulation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old smoker presents with chronic productive cough and progressive dyspnea for 2 years. Physical examination revealed a barrel chest and poor air entry. Which of the following will not be seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is characterized by an increased residual volume.

According to Uptodate, decreased vital capacity and increased total lung capacity is indicative of hyperinflation seen in COPD. FVC can be used a proxy for VC in normal individuals but in COPD FVC is less than VC due to air trapping, airflow limitation, and small airway collapse.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

 Decreased

Decreased

FEV1

Greatly decreased 

Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/Increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/Decreased

TLC

Normal/Elevated

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO

Asthma : Normal or Increased

Emphysema: Decreased

Intrinsic restrictive disease: Decreased

Neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease: Normal 

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

questions.text: The fluid of choice for resuscitation in the first 24 hours in a burns patient is ________.
questions.solution:
The fluid of choice for resuscitation in a burns patient is Ringer lactate in the first 24 hours followed by albumin and 5% dextrose.

This is in contrast to blunt and penetrating trauma patients in whom colloids (albumin, hydroxyethyl starch) hypertonic saline, and blood are preferred.

Recent Update: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula.

According to ATLS 10th edition,2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA.

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × %TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with decreased hearing. The skull radiograph shows the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and cotton wool skull appearance on the radiograph are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Paget's disease is a disease of bone remodelling. Normally, osteoclasts remove the old bones while osteoblasts form new bones. In this disease,  osteoclasts are more active than osteoblasts. leading to more bone absorption than normal. The osteoblasts try to keep up by making new bone, but they overreact and make excess bone that is abnormally large, deformed and fits together haphazardly.

Increased bone formation in Paget's disease may lead to the narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This causes compression of the cranial nerves which may lead to deafness, as seen in this patient. Deafness due to the narrowing of cranial nerve foramina is also seen in osteopetrosis. It can be differentiated from Paget's disease by the absence of lytic lesions of the bone.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

Option A: In thalassemia, X-ray of the skull will show crew cut appearance. 

Option C: In the skull X-ray, Multiple myeloma shows multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma. 

Option D: In Eosinophilic granuloma, the characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a bevelled-edge appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Meckel’s Diverticulum?

choices.text: Can be a lead point for intussusception
The most common presenting symptom is bleeding in younger children
Most common heterotropic tissue is Gastric Mucosa

questions.solution:
Meckel’s Diverticulum is a true diverticulum as it contains all the layers of the intestine. 

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • approximately 2 inches in length
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of failure of normal regression of vitello-intestinal duct :

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Class 1 and Class 3 Anti-Arrhythmic drugs
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulfate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion, or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a thyroidectomy specimen done for thyroid swelling in a 40-year-old female shows the following image. The diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei is seen in the histopathology picture which is a feature of Papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of thyroid:

  • Histologically, papillary carcinomas may exhibit papillary projections, a mixed pattern of papillary and follicular structures, or a pure follicular pattern (follicular variant).
  • The diagnosis is established by characteristic nuclear cellular features.
  • Cells are cuboidal with pale, abundant cytoplasm, crowded nuclei that may demonstrate “grooving,” and intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (leading to the designation of Orphan Annie nuclei) which allow diagnosis by FNAC.
  • Papillary tumor is very seldom encapsulated and has brownish black fluid.
  • They are usually multicentric.

questions.text: MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper to shield the imager from external electromagnetic radiation. It is called ______
questions.solution:
MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper called Faraday cage, which provides RF shielding.

Radiofrequency shielding in MRI is crucial to prevent both external radiofrequency pulses from interfering with the detector and the radiofrequency pulses generated by the scanner from interfering with the external environment.

questions.text: A 52-year old man is administered the CAGE questionnaire. What is being assessed in this patient?
questions.solution:
CAGE scale is used for alcohol abuse

  • C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking?
  • A - Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
  • G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about you drinking?
  • E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)?

One 'yes' response raises a suspicion of an alcohol use problem and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence.

questions.text: Periodic acid Schiff positive macrophages are seen in:
questions.solution:
Periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages are seen in Whipple's disease.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

 

Investigation Disease

Quantitative test: 24-hour fecal fat  (>7 gm)

Qualitative test: Sudan III staining

C14 Trioline breath test

Fecal steatocrit

 Fat malabsorption

d-Xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test

 Carbohydrate malabsorption
C13 egg-white breath test Protein malabsorption

Stool chymotrypsin

Stool elastases

 Pancreatic insufficiency
Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti TTG)

Celiac disease

  • Sensitive and specific
  • Most commonly done
Anti-endomysial antibody

Celiac disease

  • Most specific
PAS-positive macrophages in lamina propria Whipple’s disease
Biopsy confirms a diagnosis in

Whipple’s disease

Abetalipoproteinemia

Agammaglobulinemia

Biopsy finding 

  • Villous atrophy
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Normal mucosal thickness
  • Infiltrates in lamina propria
 Celiac disease 
Jejunal aspirate  >105 CFU Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
Jejunal aspirate >103 CFU For SIBO due to Enterobacter and Pseudomonas

questions.text: A 20-year-old male who is diagnosed to have acute appendicitis has worsened for the ​last few hours. X-ray was taken and is given below. What is the most likely complication that he has developed?
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray reveals air under diaphragm which is diagnostic of pneumoperitoneum. Here the perforation of bowel has resulted in pneumoperitoneum.

Classic signs in pneumoperitoneum
Rigler's Sign: Air is seen on both sides of the bowel wall
Falciform ligament sign: Air outlines the falciform ligament
Football sign: Air outlines the confines of the peritoneal cavity
Inverted V sign: Air outlines the Lateral umbilical ligament
Cupola sign: Air outlines the median subphrenic space

questions.text: Most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis is
questions.solution:
Pain is the most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis.

Characteristics of pain abdomen due to chornic pancreatitis:

  • Usually mid-epigastric in location but may localize or involve either the left or right upper quadrant of the abdomen.
  • Frequently described as penetrating through to the back.
  • Typically steady and boring, but not colicky.
  • Patients with chronic pancreatic pain typically flex their abdomen and either sit or lie with their hips flexed, or lie on their side in a fetal position.
  • Anorexia is the most common associated symptom.
  • Burned out pancreatitis –
    • The pain of chronic pancreatitis may decrease or disappear completely over a period of years, as symptoms of exocrine and endocrine deficiency become apparent.
    • It indicates progression to more severe stage.

questions.text: Apixaban is a:
questions.solution:
Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (Venous Thrombo Embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirud

Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

The FDA recently approved the drug Apixaban for a new indication. The drug is now used to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Stepwise approach :

1) pH = 7.12 (<7.35) → acidosis

2) Since pCO2= 50 (>40) it is respiratory acidosis

3) HCO3 = 28(>24) suggesting there is metabolic compensation

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 8 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is posted for laparoscopic appendectomy. which of the following inhalational agent is preferred for induction?
questions.solution:
Induction agent of choice in pediatric anesthesia is sevoflurane.

Although both halothane and sevoflurane provide a smooth induction, sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane and is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anesthesia.

Isoflurane and desflurane are airway irritants. Hence not used for induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during maintenance of anesthesia.

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker presents with pain along the left arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the left lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour).

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall. It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve palsy with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER after an RTA and requires a large amount of fluids to be transfused. Which of the following IV cannula is preferred?
questions.solution:
Grey coloured IV cannula is required for this patient in order to transfuse large amount of fluids.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a past medical history of generalized seizures controlled with phenytoin therapy. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following supplementations could have prevented this anemia?
questions.solution:
Folic acid supplementation could have prevented this patient's anemia.

This patient has mild megaloblastic anemia (high MCV), probably due to chronic phenytoin therapy. Some anti-epileptic drugs like phenytoin, phenobarbital can cause megaloblastic anemia by impairing absorption of folate in the small intestine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?
questions.solution:
The feeling of insects crawling under the skin, also known as cocaine bugs or formication, is a feature of cocaine abuse.

Other features of acute cocaine intoxication are delusions of persecution, paranoia, and suspiciousness. It is essential to differentiate acute cocaine intoxication from acute schizophrenia which it closely resembles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy finding is shown in the image. What is the most suitable treatment among the following in this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal shaped cystine stone. Hence the best suitable treatment in a patient with right-sided cysteine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cysteine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. ECWL is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric obstruction, calyceal diverticula, distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stone, calcium oxalate stone.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

  • Cystine stones: Hexagonal
  • Uric acid stones: Varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms)
  • Calcium oxalate
    • Monohydrate: Dumbbell shaped
    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle?
questions.solution:
Vas deferens does not form a boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. X-ray is done and is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are most suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP-view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

questions.text: Diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is   _______
questions.solution:
HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR.

  • NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18months
  • Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) that are commonly used for HIV testing in adults and older children are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally acquired maternal antibody until 18 months after birth.For this reason, HIV virologic testing must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA to diagnose HIV infection in children and infants younger than 18 months.Scheduled repeated testing is necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure and very recent infection will not be detectable.
  • Cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the sample with maternal blood.

questions.text: USG of a 26 year old G2P1L1 shows T sign. This is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy.  It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

The sonographic image shows the “T” sign in a monochorionic diamnionic gestation at 30 weeks. The second picture is a schematic diagram of the “T” sign. A “T” is formed at the point at which amnions meet the placenta.

In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy sonographic image depicts a  “twin-peak” sign or the “lambda sign". The below image shows a Schematic diagram of the “twin-peak” sign. A triangular portion of placenta is seen insinuating between the amniochorion layers.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Identify the incision for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
• Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the  umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line
  • Rockey–Davis incision : Transverse right lower quadrant incision.
  • Gridiron incision : Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.
  • Rutherford–Morrison incision : oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary (shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: Widening of the metaphyseal ends in rickets is known as:
questions.solution:
Widening of the metaphyseal ends is known as splaying. It occurs because of the accumulation of non-mineralized osteoid at the metaphyseal ends.

Defective mineralization of osteoid also results in fraying and cupping. Fraying is the worn-out appearance of the metaphyseal margins. Cupping is the concave appearance of the metaphysis. Bowing is seen in the diaphysis of the long bones affected by rickets.

The given radiograph shows splaying, fraying and cupping.

questions.text: A 25-year-old asthma patient is on SABA and daily low dose inhaled corticosteroids has been experiencing daily exacerbations . Which of the following medications should be added to his regimen?
questions.solution:
Daily exacerbations indicate the patient has moderate persistent asthma.

Long acting bronchodilators (LABA) should be added to his regimen.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms

TYPE  DAY SYMPTOMS NIGHT SYMPTOMS FEV1 Treatment
  Mild intermittent ≤2 days/week ≤2nights/month >80%

 As needed SABA ± low dose ICS

(step1)
Mild persistent >2 days/week >2nights/month <80% Step1 + Daily low dose ICS
Moderate persistent Daily >1night/week 60-80%

 Step1 + Daily low dose ICS+ LABA
 Severe persistent           Continual,frequent 4-7nights/week <60

Medium dose ICS + LABA

+/- add-on therapy*

 NOTE: If there is no relief even with the regimen for severe persistent asthma, High dose ICS + LABA + oral steroids +/- add-on therapy is tried. *Add-on therapy includes long-acting anticholinergics, leukotriene antagonists, mast cell stabilizers, methylxanthines, and antibodies.

 

ICS: Inhaled Corticosteroids

SABA: Short-acting beta-agonists

LABA: Long-acting beta-agonists

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image above is alopecia areata. Classically, it causes fine stippled pitting of the nails.

It is a chronic inflammatory disease which causes non-scarring patches of hair loss, especially in genetically predisposed.

The most characteristic lesion is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia, which has short extractable broken hairs called as exclamation mark hair. However, there is always sparing of white hairs in the region affected.

Other options :

Subungal oil drop sign is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discolouration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

 

Leukonychia striata are lines that extend across the nail and lie parallel to lunula. They are seen in Hypoalbuminemic states such as nephrotic syndrome .

 

Nail Pterygium is a wing-shaped deformity of nail due to a central fibrotic band which divides the nail into two parts in the proximal.

  • Dorsal pterygium is seen in lichen planus.
  • Ventral pterygium is seen in trauma, systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, lupus erythematosus, familial subungual pterygium, and infections.

questions.text: A very tall patient with a thyroid swelling and elevated calcitonin is posted for surgery. He has long, slender fingers and toes. Which preoperative screening is recommended in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a thyroid swelling, elevated calcitonin and features of marfanoid habitus (long slender fingers) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines.

A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation).

MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as:

  • Familial MTC
  • MEN 2A
  • MEN 2B

It is necessary to pre-operatively screen for pheochromocytoma in suspected cases of MEN 2 syndromes. If patients are found to have a pheochromocytoma, this must be operated on first.

Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

Known as Sipple’s syndrome

Chromosome 10 / RET gene

Associated conditions :

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

Known commonly as MEN 3

Chromosome 10/ RET gene

Features

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Associated abnormalities (40–50%)
    • Mucosal neuromas
    • Marfanoid habitus
    • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
    • Megacolon
